hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: A delegation of four hundred men (or four hundred households) from the Azd tribe of Shanua came to the Prophet ﷺ after Uhud. When they came to the Prophet ﷺ, he said: 'Welcome to the Azd, the best-looking people with faces, the bravest in meeting, the sweetest-tongued (most truthful in speech), and the greatest in trustworthiness. You are from me and I am from you, your banner O righteous ones.' Meaning: the sweetest-tongued means the most truthful in speech.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: The Prophet ﷺ wrote letters to tribes from the tribes of Mudar calling them to Allah Mighty and Majestic, and sent two or three men—there is doubt from Abu Jamrah—one of them from the Helpers (Ansar). They went with that letter to that tribe, he presented it to them and read it to them, but they denied it and did not accept it, and they killed one of the two men or one of the messengers—there is doubt from Abu Jamrah. Then the Prophet ﷺ said: 'Indeed, if I had sent this letter of mine to a people at the coast from the people of Oman from this clan of Azd, they would have confirmed me and accepted my letter.' Then a man from the Ansar, called Ka'b ibn Ujrah, sprang up and said: 'With my father and mother be your ransom O Messenger of Allah, what prevents you from writing to our brothers? By Allah, if they were in the pre-Islamic period the strongest of us as men, the most capable in carrying, and the farthest in reaching. They settled at the shore of the sea and controlled the sea. Were it not that the land is distant, they would have come as their brothers from the Shanua came. So the Prophet ﷺ wrote to them a letter and sent a man from the Ansar. Then a man from Abdul-Qais sprang up and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, send me with them as I will guide the way and know it.' So he wrote a letter and addressed it to their king Ibn Jalanda and the people of Yemen, and said to the two messengers: 'Indeed, he will accept my letter and believe me, both he and the people of Oman will believe in me. And Ibn Jalanda will ask you: Did the Messenger of Allah ﷺ send with you a gift? Say no. And he will say: Indeed, if he had sent with you a gift it would have been like the table that was sent down upon the Messiah for the Children of Israel. When they came to him they accepted Islam and his king accepted Islam and they believed in the Prophet ﷺ, and his king sent to the Prophet ﷺ a gift and sent with them from the charity of his wealth. The people of Oman accepted Islam and sent the charity of their wealth. They sent a delegation of ten, among them Abu Sufrah and Abu al-Mahaliba, and he sent a man from the offspring of a king called Ka'b ibn Shawr, and the rest of the delegation from the offspring of Jalanda and from the offspring of a king. They came to Madinah and the Prophet ﷺ had been taken (died) and Abu Bakr was made the Caliph, so the gift was given to Abu Bakr, then Ali ibn Abi Talib sprang up and said: 'This is the gift of Ibn Jalanda to the Prophet ﷺ, this is not Fadak.' Ibn Abbas said: 'So I do not know whether he divided it or put it in the treasury with the charity. Ibn Abbas said: If he divided it, we would have known that. For al-Abbas it would have been half of it and for Fatimah it would have been half of it.'

One pilgrimage from it equals two pilgrimages from other places.'

hadiths.english_translation: A man from the Azd tribe from Tahiyyah named Bairah ibn Asad migrated to Madinah. He arrived in Madinah after the Prophet ﷺ had died. When Umar ibn al-Khattab saw Bairah walking through the streets of Madinah, he did not recognize him and asked: 'Who are you?' He replied: 'I am a man from the people of Oman from the Azd tribe.' Umar took his hand and went with him to Abu Bakr and said: 'O Abu Bakr, this is from the land about which I heard the Prophet ﷺ say...'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Hawala: We were with the Prophet ﷺ and complained to him of poverty, nakedness, and scarcity of possessions. He said: 'Rejoice! By Allah, I fear for you from abundance more than from scarcity. By Allah, this matter will never cease among you until armies are divided into three groups—one army in the Levant, one army in Iraq, and one army in Yemen—until a man is given a hundred dinars and becomes displeased with it.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Hawala: I came to the Prophet ﷺ when he was under a tree writing down people's names. He raised his head to me and said: 'O Abdullah ibn Hawala, shall I write you?' I said: 'What Allah Mighty and Majestic and His Messenger have chosen for me.' He said: 'I saw Abu Bakr and Umar in the book.' I said: 'They do not write except for good.' So I said: 'Yes.' So he wrote me down. Then he said: 'O Abdullah ibn Hawala, how will you be when tribulation comes in the corners of the earth like waves of the sea?' He said: 'You must make your provision in the Levant.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Junadah al-Azdi: I entered upon the Prophet ﷺ with a group of the Azd—I was the eighth of them—on a Friday while we were fasting. He called us to food that was before him. We said: 'We are fasting.' He said: 'Did you fast yesterday?' We said: 'No.' He said: 'Will you fast tomorrow?' We said: 'No.' He said: 'Then break your fast.' So we broke our fast.
